Hello my friends!
I just published the 3rd pard of my article series about creating a React app. This week we connect our app to a remote REST API / backend. Have a nice read!

data.message: Do you mean the source code or a running version of the app?
The running version. I want to see what the app is about and test it.

I'm sorry, I did not deploy the app anywhere, but you can easily try it on your own, it's just 3 commands. See the README of my repository: 
https://github.com/areiterer/contacts-manager
Well, I ran the app but I only see a list of names. There is no way to add more records or delete existing.

That is the current state of the app. It's a multi-part article series, and with every part I'll add some functionality. In this part I handle reading data from a remote API and displaying the retrieved data. 
This is also, what the first paragraph of the article says. 

For the fully functional app you'll unfortunately have to wait a bit longer. But I'm happy to help if you've got some other questions?
I was hoping to see the final version because I believe people should know what they are working towards.

Yavor Spassov good point. I'm just coding along the articles this time. But I definitely plan to show a full running version of the app that I'm going to build in my book. So everyone can see what we're going to build before he/she purchases the book. 

Thank you for the valuable feedback!
Is there a link to the final app's working version?

Thanks! You can use any REST API with React that you want. In the article you can see, that there are several tools to perform AJAX calls: XHRequest, fetch, axios, superagent

Find one that you like the best (try them all for the beginning) and then you can use them in every React app to do AJAX calls.

data.message:
Well I converted from VueJS to React for my current project and the whole process was very smooth. I don't understand why all the fuss. I was a little bit prejudiced about JSX but it didn't even touch me (JSX with emmet is just like HTML with emmet). Also writing in JSX it feels more javascript. I learned React from a known video tutor in a day, and the whole basic port took about 2 days. Now its time to discover redux too and compare it to Vuex.

Yeah I know, I learned from the opposite order Vue->React. But I think the reason that I grasped so easily React, was that I had already understood the whole concept.
I know React and learn Vuejs, Ractive js very easy
Where is it from?
npmtrends.com
This graph says it all.
Peter Absolon I don't take account those graphs too much. Don't forget that you can include Vue via script tag and not from npm. Even Vue docs suggest to include the library via script from unpkg cdn

Yeah, sure, it's skewed. Thing is, while Vue is great, it doesn't have the community and support (FB) that React has. Also jobs. You don't see a lot of Vue job postings. That's the dealbreaker for me.

By video tutor I mean simple videos, not 1:1 teacher. Look, in my opinion the whole thing is the concept. Once you understand the concept you will grasp easily the library. Because I'm using vue 2 years now, the transition was very smooth.
Thanks. I think I need to just stick with it, I'm learning there are lots of variables that come with it but it's been worth it. Just different.
Are you familiar with javascript? (especially ES6)? Or did you dive suddenly in react?

Very familiar with native Javascript and getting used to ES6 now but I wasn't familiar with Node, npm libraries or Ajax. So I took a step back from React and starting focusing Ajax. Oddly, I now understand Ajax, JSON and Routing believe it or not. But now i'm more confused on other areas but at least I now understand why React is needed. Bottom line is I'm learning but not at the pace I'd like if I had a mentor, which is the reason I asked you how you were doing it.
Are you in class physically or are you learning from skype? I'm trying to learn from books and videos but I think I should have a personal tutor myself.

Peter Absolon I have an objection for the community support. I think it's very good. Whenever I had an issue I solved it fast (don't forget that is has 70K stars on github). It's community is very active. But for jobs I have to agree with you. Oh boy, everyone wants react, and one reason I forced to learn react is this.

data.message: Hi guys, what is the most SEO friendly way of doing 404 redirections which depence on ajax call? Should I use "Redirect" from react-router-dom?

Do you really know what bind is? First parameter of bind is just a 'this' in the function.

The first bind argument is a reference from `this` inside the function.

The second bind argument (and the rest) is the function arguments that will be applied to.

const sum = (a, b) => a + b
const sumBy2 = sum.bind(null, 2)

sum(2, 3) // 5
sumBy2(3) // 5
in sumBy2 b=2 ok? :D

and in sumBy2(3), a=2, b=3

Welcome to the ReactJS group. Please take a moment to read the following rules to keep this community more friendly.
1. Please keep links relative to React development
2. Don't promote paid content in the group
3. Job posting is allowed, but it should be related to React/React Native
4. Please write post in English
Yeah...actually we got lots of people come from Taiwan and China and use Mandarin. So, do you have any suggestion?
This group is awesome, except when people post promoted, clickbait or irrelevant posts. I even like when people post their blogs and apps for us to critique. :)
Yep, I really like people share their blogs, apps or side projects on this community. It's very helpful for us to learn more about React.
There are lots of local groups, so if someone wants to use other language => go to other groups
We have a big community outside of the English language though and many people respond with their language 😲
Agree. I also prefer keeping this group international. Thank you Peter Šulek.
Other thing is it should be better managed to filter out spammers, etc. If you need help with administration, i can help.
Sure. Nobody likes to see lots of spams. I will add a few of React enthusiast as the moderator to help to keep this community clean. Very appreciate it! Thanks.
I do report posts ( report to admin option ) very ofter, would be nice if someone take care of that.

We should use here only English. You will not understand my native language (Slovak) as i don't understand others (Chinese, etc..) and surely there are some local groups for reactjs in your language. 
So lets have this group international.

I don't thing job posting is relevant here when this group is international. So i don't agree to have jobs offer in this group. Mitch Chen what do you think? It should be stated in group rules pinned post, if job posts are allowed or not.
Aren't most programming jobs international now anyway? Or at least a significant number of them? Perhaps limit it to jobs which are available to remote folks in a majority of the world?

Aaron Cannon I like idea of remote jobs. But be honest, at least for me, i'm also in local group of developers where i'm interested in job posting. But in groups like this i just want technical resources and not jobs where 99% will not be interesting for me... Just my opinion.
That makes sense. Either way, it should be spelled out, whatever the policy.

It's pretty obvious that you want to put yourself as a moderator, but you are missing a huge point here. Facebook groups are all about connecting. It doesn't have to be used for technical stuff only. There are Stackoverflow-liike websites for that. Meanwhile, facebook groups are more suitable for sharing news, opinions and experiences related to React, and for React devs to connect with each other. That also includes job postings. While I agree that English only group rule is fine, I think that you are underestimating technology a little bit and the fact that facebook or any other translating engine translates everything back to your selected language so it doesn't matter in which language you write. That being said, it means that more people would be able to connect easier. Just my five cents. Peter Šulek

It's a good issue to discuss with you guys. I think job posting related to React is ok. Maybe it is posted by recruiter, but it also means that someone needs help from this community. I will state it in group rules. Thank you guys.

Krunoslav Zvonimir i don't want to be a moderator because i can denied job posting. I just offer my help with moderating this group as i already moderating other groups. I just express my opinion about job posting. But it's up to us to decide about group rules. Mitch Chen maybe we can do pool about job posting if members want that.

I think we have to differentiate here: For instance I do not like "job offers" where recruiters just post an untrusted address where you may fill their database with your personal data, CV etc. 
On the other side I am 100% ok when a programmer/developer/expert is looking for SPECIFIC help on specific issues that can be done short term and remote. 
The test would be, how detailed the SPECIFIC job/work offer is specified and how much we can trust the people behind it. 
After all, whoever is going to post a job offer, should be/must be ready to discuss this job offer HERE and is expected to have a clue about what he is talking about!
René Baron Fully agreed
@aaron cannon I think we should post jobs here relevant to freelancing and remote jobs because a lot of companies are adopting it successfully...

Aaron Cannon your quote: "Aren't most programming jobs international now anyway?"
I think it depends on the requirements and the market. 
For small, noncomplex me-too projects (<= 1 Man Year of work) you are right. Wherever the big money is paid for complex, business-critical extensions to already existing, large enterprise solutions it is still a huge advantage to be able to communicate face to face from time to time. 
I am doing international projects now for 30+ years. Despite technology advantages, I am still flying more and working with the client on spot than before.

Is there anyone using GraphQL? I need some advise on the development stack. 

I have been doing some research and found that some stacks are like : 

1. React + GraphQL + Redux + Apollo 
2. React + GraphQL + Redux 

Since I havent tried out Apollo yet , can someone please briefly explain the difference or the pros and cons between the Stack 1 & 2 mentioned above ?

Thanks bro
Yes but we can use graphql without apollo right ?
yes, using another client
Krzysztof Gardocki so apollo is must to use it with graphql

if you're willing to reinvent the wheel.  It's pretty obvious that you need a client if you are using GraphQL so just start building a page that communicates with the server using GraphQL.  Doesn't have to be Apollo though.  Like I mentioned, Relay is an alternative option.
Please correct me thanks
Simone Li you need apollo, redux is optional in this case eg. for managing app state (UI) rather than data
so. would you use apollo 2.0 with redux? aint it an overkill?

GraphQL client basically generates the payload `{ query: '...', variables: {...} }` which is sent to server via an AJAX call. If you can write a small helper for same, you can avoid using yet another library like Apollo or Relay. And advantage of writing your own simple helper function which generates the payload will let you use your favorite state management (eg: Redux) in your React app. Example of such GraphQL query builder helper function: https://github.com/atulmy/fullstack-graphql/blob/master/webapp/src/setup/helpers.js#L8
As its name tells, GraphQL is a query language for your API.  Apollo is a GraphQL client.  Relay/Apollo are the two most famous GraphQL clients.
You wanna use Apollo

This is what I am wondering too. 
Not sure if I should have apollo + redux

I'm using Apollo in my company project, and I had to use redux in some locations (the product's Cart that is stored locally, for example). But it's VERY COMMON to see applications that use Apollo and not use Redux.

You can use redux to handle UI state also. For example, if you have a "menu drawer", could want to store "isOpened" state globally to trigger from anywhere. But you should try to store UI state locally whenever possible.
is it viable to use apollo+redux? I think apollo is enough but i don't know. please let me know what you think? i see apollo as easier version of relay

Try this
https://dev-blog.apollodata.com/full-stack-react-graphql-tutorial-582ac8d24e3b
Nice
Will the auth function be JWT or session ?
These are the options. I wanted to implement simple session email password auth. Auth0 would be easier though.
Auth0

Apollo itself will not be enough when your application grows. You will need some global state management if you plan to have for example authorization. I have recently created React Apollo boilerplate.

It has
React Apollo 2.0.2
React 16.0.1
React Router 4.2.2
Recompose 0.26.0 (no classes here)
Redux 3.7.2
Webpack 3.8.1
Styled Components 2.2.3

Nightwatch for e2e testing.

https://github.com/developer239/ReactReduxApolloGraphQLHotBoilerplate

If you want to see something implemented feel free to create an issue. I plan to integrate simple email, password authorization by the end of the next week. I am not sure though what would people like to see next.
I believe you are wrong. Redux is basically a fancy state management. If you need something stored "globally" then you want to use redux.
that was what i was thinking too. but how about subscriptions and auth? don't you think you need apollo server on that approach?

Michal Jarnot https://dev-blog.apollodata.com/whats-coming-in-apollo-client-2-0-bcd8ea64acbd quoting from the post "Managing application state using GraphQL (my personal favorite)" see this comment. https://medium.com/@sachagreif/this-could-be-pretty-powerful-9165997ba07d  please let me know what you think

Glendon Philipp Baculio This one looks interesting. I will definitely do some research on apollo link. However after a first glance it looks like apollo link is meant to share server / client state? What about client only state? It is pretty hard to believe that apollo could replace flux itself... I might be wrong though. :)

I will recommend to avoid using Redux if you are using GraphQL. A framework like Apollo client should do all state management for you. Using Redux with Apollo client is an overkill. For server side of GraphQL, avoid Apollo server and use Express-GraphQL which is anyway the recommended approach. No Redux on the client, No Apollo server. But use Apollo client with Express-GraphQL. I also blogged about it a bit earlier - https://vijayt.com/post/when-should-we-use-graphql/

Auth - check out auth-graphql-starter from StephenGrider in git. If you don't like sessions, swap it out with tokens. I have a repo - vijayst/birdapi which has token based auth with JWT. No redux or Apollo server.

You can check this out: https://github.com/atulmy/crate featuring Node + Express + GraphQL + React + Redux + JWT Auth + SSR + React Storybook. [work in progress, but core of the backend/frontend is ready which you can clone and check out]
yes. and their documentation is not so good than apollo. especially on subscriptions, though mutations are understandable.

2. Should be React + GraphQL + Relay (IMHO)  

Apparently Relay is a somewhat more complex but also more powerful solution (backed by Facebook) than Apollo.

data.message: Difference () => () and () => {} in arrow function ES6?

() => {} is a function.
() => () is not valid es6 code. What instead you can do is wrapping something in (). Like an object.
() => ({ a: 1 }).

1. () => ()   direct return value
like this () => ({ text: 'hello' }), return an object {text: 'hello'} immediately
2. () => {}  you need to write return or it will return undefined
() => { return { text: 'hello' } }
() => () is implicit return
With {} you need to have return to return the value. With () object or whatever inside is will be returned. And, it has to be one statement.
*Expression
If you only have one statement in the function you can avoid using the curly braces, () => (console.log('Look! No curly braces')). Also like mentioned before return is implicit.
() means it’s returning just whatever’s inside, specially with react JSX, {} means what’s in there is a function
Syed Zain Ali

() implicit return
vs
{} multi line code, probably to do some extra stuff before returning
yes
but `return` must be included if curly braces are used? Right?

well... console.log dont return anything (it default to undefined)
probably better example.. will be some math operation ....
Moises Man thank you I put some text into it

const noReturn2 = (x,y) => console.log(x,y) 

const mustReturn2 = (x,y) => { return console.log(x,y) }

() => () allows you to have json inside or multiple logical operations, but essentially, with multiple logical operations you do not need brackets. In {} is same as function, so you will have to create return statement in order for the calling method to get results or its inner logic to be satisfied.

For example [1,2,3,4].filter(value => value%2===0).map((currentValue, key, array) => {  if(currentValue%key===0) { return NaN } return currentValue }).slice(-1)[0];
as well const add3 = (x,y) => ({ sum: x+y }); (fixed)
yep.. but ur "arrow/equal" is on wrong position :)🤔
yep :-D
Implicit return.

() allows expression, while {} allows statements. Basically when you use (), it will always return value passed in. It's same as using { return ()} block. While using {}, you can add multiple statements, (for example: multiple function calls) and you do not necessary need to return any value from that block.

Just want to ask something about FlowType
(Exact object types)

as you can see, i have a function that have a "values" argument with a type of "firstname" and "lastname".

How come flow doesn't detect an error on the second If statement "(values.noProperty)" when i declare that only firstname and lastname should exist on values object.

Now flow returns me an error if i try to access the property
"(values.noProperty.secondProp)"

Anyone encountered this? Cheers.

Yeah, but i defined the ‘values’ to only have firstname and lastname property. On the 2nd if, which is 
If(values.noProperty), flow should give me an error because im using Exact Object Types

FlowType know that `values` is an object. Then, if you call a prop `values.noProperty` it will be undefined, but will not throw any errors.

Otherwise, since noProperty is undefined, so you can not call prop `values.noProperty.secondProp`. It will throw error "cannot access secondProp of undefined"

Pass props down

Just pass via props from parent to children.
A step further, wrap your main App.js (smart) component in the Redux Provider component to pass props down from your Store/DB.

In Javascript, function statements are scoped within the containing function (or globally if there is no containing function), they're not scoped within an if or else or loop block. So you can't declare a function conditionally in that manner (it can be done another way; see below). And if you declare more than one function with the same name in the same scope the later one will overwrite the first one.

So what happens with your code is:

Both function statements are hoisted, but

They both have the same name so the first is overwritten by the second.

The variable, a is created but not yet assigned a value.

The foo() statement is executed, logging "b"

a is assigned the value true.

The if is executed. The condition is true, but neither the if nor else branches actually do anything because they don't contain statements other than the function declarations that were hoisted earlier.

If you want to create functions conditionally you have to declare a variable and then assign a function expression to it. And then you can not call the function until after that assignment:

var foo; var a = true; if(a) foo = function() { console.log("a"); }; else foo = function() { console.log("b"); }; foo();
Note that var doesn't have block scope either, it has function scope, but the newer variable declaration keywords let and const do have block scope.

Ante Gulin Flow doesn't support making dependency between type definitions. This causes two problems.

1. To define new typedef of lib depends on complex (large) lib, you should copy-and-paste typedef of that complex lib and rename them (because of naming convention of flow-typed).
2. After defining some typedef, you need to sync it manually when its deps are updated.

data.message: Yes - I thought it was a good idea to start with the basics and then working up to the advanced stuff. Is there something special you would like to read about?
I'm looking into integrating react with an express app. I'm currently reviewing express tutorials and documentation to get me going. The MERN framework

In terms of Server Side Rendering? That's a bit difficoult. 

But if you mean you have an express backend (REST API) you would fetch the data from there - this is part of my next article in the series :) Or did I misunderstand something?

If you want to create a Express Backend AND a React App that gets the data from it, I would suggest you have a look at how to create an Express REST API first. 
Then learn how to fetch data from a backend (fetch, axios, superagent, etc) 

I think that's the best way to go there.

Andreas Reiterer When is your book going to finish?

As I hit the goal of subscribers that I set myself, I started my research and plan to publish the first chapter by the end of the year. As the research and the start is most of the work, I think the whole book will be out somewhere in March/April. 
But I plan to add a preorder option so people can get the chapters as they are ready, so they don't have to wait until the whole book is finished.
